This is Jamie Rollo's team, who are the go-sources on cruise industry demand. Here's the gist of it.

BE11:21am

Qualitative survey of US travel agents shows a weakening picture. Booking volumes remain positive, and May was described as "unusually strong" by some agents, with Europe demand pulling ahead, aided by reasonable air fares. Smaller ships, all inclusive, river and luxury cruises continue to fare better than mainstream. On the negative side, overall pricing is described as flat, which is sequentially weaker; the impact of K ī lauea has affected Hawaii bookings, many agents cite Q3/Q4 Caribbean as being a concern (reflecting both hurricane worries and too much capacity), and some top retailers report worries about a general slowdown hitting Q4 2018 that will impact 2019 departures (early discounting for select 2019 sailings a "troubling sign"). The Caribbean remains the main market to watch out for, and according to our channel checks, RCL seems to be in a better position here compared to CCL, but RCL does have a larger Caribbean exposure.

RA @soundbuy, i cant go to that, id be too tempted to kick over the bottom box. i dont know whats wrong with me.
Soundbuy @RA - you'd struggle.........https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vml5dvuTkz8
11:22 am
BE11:22am

After that you have oil up and euro down vs the dollar, which doesn't happen often.

BE11:22am

Usually the two move in lockstep, creating a natural hedge. Not right now.

BE11:23am

RA oh they're suspended. thats more interesting
BornCynic Agent orange - they injected that into black prisoners to see what happened:https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/17/us/dioxin-tests-conducted-in-60-s-on-70-philadelphia-inmates-now-unknown.html
11:23 am
BE11:23am

So .... we have industry supply growth, slowing yield momentum and weakness in both the Caribbean and China

BE11:24am

Globally, the cruise industry orderbook has risen to a record 244k berths (45% supply growth to 2025), a 6.3% 2018-21 CAGR (or ~5.5% net of scrappage, which is currently minimal). So for the industry to maintain, say, 2-3% yield growth, demand would need to grow by 7.5-9.5% annually, which for four consecutive years seems optimistic and is much more than historical levels (6% demand, 1% yield, 5% capacity). CCL is starting to look relatively expensive on an FY19e P/E of 15x vs RCL and NCLH both on 11x, so we think RCL/NCLH are more attractive than CCL, and trading CCL off against the others could be rewarding in the context of our cautious industry view. CCL reports Q2 later this month and we are negative ahead of the results

BE11:24am

Hope that's helpful.

11:24 am

(@waynej: it was well flagged in the months sense but perhaps not in the days sense, so I'm not sure how much fast money was in position. Was there much?)

BE11:30am

Here's a bit from John Cronin of Goodbody, who does an excellent financial wrap each morning.

FATDAZ @Pharma agreed
11:30 am
BE11:30am

we must admit that we felt that last week’s news of the resignation of CFO Ewen Stevenson (which (inadvertently?) accelerates the need for CEO succession planning initiatives in our view) together with market dislocation would have resulted in a decision to defer any immediate disposal plans. However, despite Ewen Stevenson’s ‘recommendation’ that HMT wait to press the eject button (a lot going on behind the scenes in recent weeks clearly!), the decision was taken to proceed with the sale. While it’s hard to see how the disposal creates much political capital (latest Exchequer figures have surprised to the upside – and the shares are being sold at a considerable loss given the average in-price was 502p, with VFM considerations said to be a real concern leading up to the decision) we do welcome the move as we think that the Chancellor’s position to the effect that the State is not a long-term stockholder in the banking sector is a sensible one – though I must admit that if I were on the executive committee of RBS I would have been disappointed with the news in one vein as RBS still looks cheap and its value should become more obvious to the market in the relative near-term (though, to be fair, HMT has only just started the ball rolling – and we expect a better result on subsequent sale tranches – and this sale will potentially help that) – despite the fact that RBS shares are down c.3% at the time of writing. Notably, UKGI is now subject to a lock-up for 90 days.

Flaneur Will TM fall next week over the canard of Heathrow? .......or will she find a completely differnent canard to fall over?
BE11:31am

Though that's a soft lockup, isn't it? And we've seen again and again that lockups can be broken at a whim.

[W]e think it is conceivable that the Government could exit its stake in full by 2023e through a combination of placings and directed buybacks, but this will likely serve to “cap” the share price. HOLD.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Jefferies incoming:

kim TM may one day be seen as a hero. She's guiding the Brexiters down every rabbit hole available.
BE11:35am

We expect the next major step to value creation to be re-commencing an ordinary dividend of 6p for '18E. Whilst we expect this dividend to be paid in respect of the full year, we see no reason why RBS should not be able to announce its intention at the half year results (3 August) given BARC was able to announce its intention to pay a 6.5p dividend in respect of 2018 subject to regulatory approval. The next step on the path to value creation is the prospect that RBS could use directed buy-backs to repurchase up to 5% of HMT's stake in the bank in each of 2018 and 2019, prospectively driving an incremental 6.3p of EPS by 2020E. Meanwhile, we expect the incremental liquidity buffers built up in anticipation of the DOJ settlement - a 12bps drag on group NIM since Q1 17 - can be reversed over the next 12-18 months, liberating £510m of incremental interest income (3p/share).

BE11:35am

RBS trades on 1.0x forward TBV for a 2020E adjusted ROTE of
12.4% which we employ in a Gordon Growth framework (10% Ke; 2% growth) to value RBS on a base case of 358p. Risk/reward is asymmetric to the upside with option factors driving an upside to 423p (downside case 240p).

BE11:47am

The equity valuation remains very, very low at c.1x FY18E EPS, with the share price effectively reflecting option value on the outcome of the bond refinancing ahead of June 2019. Based on the nominal value of the bond (£220m), EV/EBITDA for FY18E is 5.6x, or 6.8x if we include the pension deficit (at IAS19 valuation). Our Target Price reduces from 45p to 30p, and remains contingent, as before, on a successful refinancing of the 2019 bond – a point on which the company notes there is “material uncertainty” in its liquidity and going concern review.

BE11:47am

That was when they were 9p.

competitive auction as likely, given IWG’s global position, free
cash generation, potential for growth and low valuation
compared to WeWork. Our takeover target price remains 320-
350p. With an undisturbed fair value of 260p, which the share
price would go below in the event of no bid, our risk-balanced
TP remains 300p. Given the current share price of 320p, our
recommendation moves to Hold.

The historical margin expansion trend has slowed to a crawl more recently, but margins could now start to step down. In FY 2018 our forecast of a 60bp decline was already below guidance and consensus (flat) given the need to refill incentive pools and the mix effect of revenue weakness in the company’s most profitable region of North America. However, we now assume that FY 2019 margins will fall another 100bp, reflecting incremental fee pressure at a time of management change, and £50m of net technology spend by a newly appointed CEO. This leaves our margins c150bp below and our EPS 9% below consensus for FY 2019. We assume margins remain flat from there in the longer term as potential restructuring cost benefits offset investment and fee pressure; so any cost savings announcements in future should not necessarily be considered additive to existing profit forecasts.

BE12:04pm

Leverage reached 2x average net debt to EBITDA in FY 2017 (on the company’s generous definition, closer to 2.5x fully adjusted), at the top end of its target range. As guided, we assume that WPP sells £750m of equity stakes and associate investments to reduce debt, but falling profitability, and the current guidance for acquisitions and buybacks to continue, indicates that leverage will still not fall meaningfully. At the same time, the earnings decline moves the dividend payout ratio above the current 50% level (at target); with a new CEO set to be appointed, there is clear scope for cash return expectations to be rebased and we now assume a flat dividend. An internal appointment for the CEO position would confirm our view that a meaningful breakup is not likely. Further smaller disposals are possible, but would further exacerbate the earnings dilution and dividend payout issue.
